I[s] a company a monopoly just because people like its products better? 
 
 
 Generally, if a company makes products that people like and it becomes the ONLY product in that category, then the company is a monopoly by definition of monopoly. This is fair monopoly, and there should a problem with it [although I don't know what the laws says exactly against this sort of stuff; I am not a business lawyer], but it's not that simple of an issue. That's a naive question for two reasons:
 
 1. Generally when a company monopolizes over something, chances are it will try to abuse the power. lawsuits against Microsoft are mostly for this reason. For example, Microsoft uses its monopoly (for the most part; it's not entirely a monopoly here) over PC OS's to try to destroy competitors in other markets like web-browsers, etc. I think this is unfair. 
 
 2. It's hard to keep yourself from asking what are the chances that a company can be so good as to be able make so many good products that people really really like? The answer is obviously that the chances are really low. In fact, it's close to impossible. How does Microsoft do it? Well, it uses the tactic in (1) to destroy competitors, and it acquires competitors with better products along the same line (almost like horizontal integration). If you examine carefully, most of the products from Microsoft aren't originally from them. Let's take a look at some examples:
 The product line of better operating systems from Microsoft (Windows NT, 2000, XP) started when Microsoft hired engineers from other companies to design the first version of Windows NT. This, essentially, is like legally stealing ideas developed by other companies. In fact, ideas used in the architecture of Windows NT were not developed by Microsoft. 
 Microsoft voice recognition engine... from another company.
 Microsoft Visio.... from another company.
 .NET framework and C#.... hired engineers from other company to develop it.
 You name it.
 
 
 So a direct answer to your question is: if a company is so good that it can make products that a lot of people like, then yeah it monopolizes that market...but fairly so. Microsoft, on the other hand, is not one of those companies.
